footnotes.footnote_text: Pewećeli is a character in the Washoe Tribe’s creation story, and Pewećeli Yeweš means “Pewećeli’s trail” or “path” in reference to a trade route heading west. Email correspondence with Herman Miller, Culture/Language Resources Director, Washoe Tribe of Nevada and California (Oct. 16, 2024) (on file with the author); see also Claire Cudahy, “Washoe youth follow ancestors’ footsteps in Hope Valley,” Tahoe Daily Tribune (Jan. 25, 2018), https://www.tahoedailytribune.com/news/local/washoe-youth-follow-ancestors-footsteps-in-hope-valley-video/; U.S. Forest Service, Carson Ranger District, East Carson River Strategy, 4-5 (July 2007), http://www.theanglersedge.com/downloads/East_Carson_River_Strategy_061907.pdf. For a history of the Washoe and the lands they inhabited, see The Washoe Tribe of Nevada and California, WA SHE SHU: “The Washoe People” Past and Present (2009), https://www.fs.usda.gov/Internet/FSE_DOCUMENTS/stelprdb5251066.pdf; Washoe Tribe of California and Nevada, Washoe History: A Brief Summary (2020), https://washoetribe.us/aboutpage/4-Page-washoe-history.

There are, of course, many other types of remands (to administrative law judges, bankruptcy courts, state courts, and so on), and in a few footnotes I have noted ways in which jurisprudence concerning such other remands is relevant to the administrative-remand rule. See infra notes 113, 151-153.

footnotes.footnote_text: Professor Bryan Lammon at the University of Toledo College of Law has written most extensively about the administrative-remand rule, though in the more general context of finality and appellate jurisdiction. See Bryan Lammon, Finality, Appealability, and the Scope of Interlocutory Review, 93 Wash. L. Rev. 1809, 1834-37 (2018); Bryan Lammon, Dizzying Gillespie: The Exaggerated Death of the Balancing Approach and the Inescapable Allure of Flexibility in Appellate Jurisdiction, 51 U. Rich. L. Rev. 371, 386-93 (2017). The rule has received passing attention in other scholarship. See, e.g., Harold J. Krent, Situating Structural Challenges to Agency Authority Within the Framework of the Finality Principle, 98 Ind. L.J. Supplement 1, 10 n.73 (2023); Jennifer L. Biever & Ana Maria Gutierrez, The Uncertain Question of Remedies Should a Challenge Prevail, 2016 NO. 5 RMMLF-INST PAPER NO. 13, 28-29 (2016); Michele D. Lynch, Remands Are A Consequence of Administrative Law, So Why Are We All So Frustrated?, 23 Tul. J. Int’l & Comp. L. 383, 392 (2015). Finally, a few treatises discuss the rule. See, e.g., Federal Practice & Procedure, § 3914.32 Orders Prior to Trial—Administrative Review, 15B Fed. Prac. & Proc. Juris. § 3914.32 (2d ed. June 2024 Update); Federal Practice & Procedure, § 3903 Pragmatic Finality, 15A Fed. Prac. & Proc. Juris. § 3913 (3d ed. June 2024 Update); see also, e.g., 73A C.J.S. Pub. Admin. Law & Proc. § 561 (May 2024); Fed. Ct. App. Manual § 2:3 (7th ed. May 2024).

Bureau of Land Mgmt., 69 F.4th 588, 597-98 (9th Cir. 2023) (Friedland and Bennett, JJ., concurring). A Second Circuit panel has expressed similar concerns. See N.Y. Legal Assistance Grp. v. Cardona, No. 21-888-CV, 2024 WL 64220, at *3-4 (2d Cir. Jan. 5, 2024).

footnotes.footnote_text: The administrative-remand rule applies to appeals to the circuit courts of district-court remand orders. There is no equivalent rule that covers appeals to the Supreme Court of circuit-court remand orders or of circuit-court decisions upholding district-court remand orders. The Supreme Court does have, however, a longstanding, general rule against interlocutory review. See Am. Constr. Co. v. Jacksonville, Tampa & Key West Ry. Co., 148 U.S. 372, 384 (1893) (“[M]any orders made in the progress of a suit become quite unimportant by reason of the final result, or of intervening matters.”).

citations.citation_text: The administrative-remand rule applies to appeals to the circuit courts of district-court remand orders. There is no equivalent rule that covers appeals to the Supreme Court of circuit-court remand orders or of circuit-court decisions upholding district-court remand orders. The Supreme Court does have, however, a longstanding, general rule against interlocutory review. See Am. Constr. Co. v. Jacksonville, Tampa & Key West Ry. Co., 148 U.S. 372, 384 (1893) (“[M]any orders made in the progress of a suit become quite unimportant by reason of the final result, or of intervening matters.”).

footnotes.footnote_text: Some courts and commentators conceive of the rule as being narrower: A decision remanding an agency action is not final and appealable, and an appeal by the agency is an “exception” to that rule instead of part of the rule itself. See infra notes 29, 94, 113. This narrow framing allows a circuit court to reject an appeal of a remand by an agency, which, we will see, the circuits almost never do. As a result, under either this narrower or my broader framing the result is the same: Typically only agencies may appeal orders remanding their decisions for further proceedings.

footnotes.footnote_text: Alsea Valley Alliance, 358. F3d at 1184 (“An agency, after all, cannot appeal the result of its own decision.”). As the Seventh Circuit put it, “an order remanding a case to an agency is final for purposes of 28 U.S.C. § 1291 if it terminates the agency’s judicial remedies other than contempt.” Crowder v. Sullivan, 897 F.2d 252, 253 (7th Cir. 1990) (per curiam); see also 15B Fed. Prac. & Proc. Juris. § 3914.32 (“The most cogent explanation for most of these decisions must be that administrative agencies, as more or less coordinate branches of government, deserve the protection of special appeal opportunities. The need to settle important questions, and to get them right, underlies the most persuasive decisions. There actually is reason to worry that an agency cannot appeal its own decision in favor of a claimant if the decision was compelled by a district court remand that the agency believes wrong.”).

citations.citation_text: Alsea Valley Alliance, 358. F3d at 1184 (“An agency, after all, cannot appeal the result of its own decision.”). As the Seventh Circuit put it, “an order remanding a case to an agency is final for purposes of 28 U.S.C. § 1291 if it terminates the agency’s judicial remedies other than contempt.” Crowder v. Sullivan, 897 F.2d 252, 253 (7th Cir. 1990) (per curiam); see also 15B Fed. Prac. & Proc. Juris. § 3914.32 (“The most cogent explanation for most of these decisions must be that administrative agencies, as more or less coordinate branches of government, deserve the protection of special appeal opportunities. The need to settle important questions, and to get them right, underlies the most persuasive decisions. There actually is reason to worry that an agency cannot appeal its own decision in favor of a claimant if the decision was compelled by a district court remand that the agency believes wrong.”).

footnotes.footnote_text: This Article avoids framing the circumstances in which the circuit courts deem remands appealable as “exceptions” to the final-judgment rule or administrative-remand rule, even though many courts do just that. The “courts of appeals do not have authority to create exceptions to congressional limits on jurisdiction.” Papotto v. Hartford Life & Accid. Insur. Co., 731 F.3d 265, 270-71 (3d Cir. 2013) (citing supporting cases). Rather, the circuit courts’ prudential development of circumstances in which remands are final, despite the general rule they are not, is simply a “practical construction of finality.” Kreider Dairy Farms, Inc. v. Glickman, 190 F.3d 113, 124 (3d Cir. 1999) (Sloviter, J., concurring); see also Digital Equip. Corp. v. Desktop Direct, Inc., 511 U.S. 863, 867 (1994) (“The collateral order doctrine is best understood not as an exception to the ‘final decision’ rule laid down in Congress in § 1291, but as a ‘practical construction’ of it.”).

Co., 731 F.3d 265, 270-71 (3d Cir. 2013) (citing supporting cases). Rather, the circuit courts’ prudential development of circumstances in which remands are final, despite the general rule they are not, is simply a “practical construction of finality.” Kreider Dairy Farms, Inc. v. Glickman, 190 F.3d 113, 124 (3d Cir. 1999) (Sloviter, J., concurring); see also Digital Equip. Corp. v. footnotes.footnote_text: Cohen, 337 U.S. at 546-47. The collateral-order doctrine gets more air time below, but for now: “This decision appears to fall in that small class which finally determine claims of right separable from, and collateral to rights asserted in the action, too important to be denied review and too independent of the cause itself to require that appellate consideration be deferred until the whole case is adjudicated.” Id. at 546. Note that the collateral-order doctrine is a judicial (prudential) construction of the final judgment rule in 28 U.S.C. § 1291, while 28 U.S.C. § 1292 is itself a set of statutory exceptions for interlocutory appeal of certain nonfinal orders. Matthew R. Pikor, The Collateral Order Doctrine in Disorder: Redefining Finality, 92 Chi.-Kent L. Rev. 619, 622 (2017).

citations.citation_text: Cohen, 337 U.S. at 546-47. The collateral-order doctrine gets more air time below, but for now: “This decision appears to fall in that small class which finally determine claims of right separable from, and collateral to rights asserted in the action, too important to be denied review and too independent of the cause itself to require that appellate consideration be deferred until the whole case is adjudicated.” Id. at 546. Note that the collateral-order doctrine is a judicial (prudential) construction of the final judgment rule in 28 U.S.C. § 1291, while 28 U.S.C. § 1292 is itself a set of statutory exceptions for interlocutory appeal of certain nonfinal orders. Matthew R. Pikor, The Collateral Order Doctrine in Disorder: Redefining Finality, 92 Chi.-Kent L. Rev. 619, 622 (2017).

footnotes.footnote_text: 437 U.S. 463 (1978). As “more or less” implies, the Court’s enforcement of the final-judgment rule has ebbed and flowed, but the general trend has been tighter appellate jurisdiction. See, e.g., Adam Reed Moore, A Textualist Defense of A New Collateral Order Doctrine, 99 Notre Dame L. Rev. Reflection 1, 11 (2023) (“In the last decade, the Court has grown skeptical of the collateral order doctrine.”); Lloyd C. Anderson, The Collateral Order Doctrine: A New “Serbonian Bog” and Four Proposals for Reform, 46 Drake L. Rev. 539, 568 (1998), 568-85 (describing ebbs and flows and the Court’s “retrenchment” from broad collateral-order review after 1985).

As “more or less” implies, the Court’s enforcement of the final-judgment rule has ebbed and flowed, but the general trend has been tighter appellate jurisdiction. See, e.g., Adam Reed Moore, A Textualist Defense of A New Collateral Order Doctrine, 99 Notre Dame L. Rev. Reflection 1, 11 (2023) (“In the last decade, the Court has grown skeptical of the collateral order doctrine.”)

Baker, 528 U.S. 23, 30-33 (2017) (recognizing such abrogation).

footnotes.footnote_text: There was, first, the decision itself, which allowed the government to appeal the district court’s remand. Second, Finkelstein facilitated the Court’s decision, eight years later, that a claimant could appeal the same type of remand at issue in Finkelstein. See Forney v. Apfel, 524 U.S. 266, 270-71 (1998). Third, Finkelstein promisingly recognized a “great variety in remands,” with one example being “a remand to the agency but the person seeking judicial review may seek to appeal on the ground that broader relief should have been granted by the district court.” Finkelstein, 496 U.S. at 623 & n.3.

footnotes.footnote_text: As Part I.D below shows, some circuit courts explicitly relied on Finkelstein to allow interlocutory appeals of remands by agencies outside the social-security context. See, e.g., Baca-Prieto v. A1 Guigni, 95 F.3d 1006, 1009 (10th Cir. 1996) (in allowing agency to appeal remand requiring it to grant habeas relief, stating: “In light of the special relevance, both historical and analytical, of practical finality considerations in the administrative-remand context, illustrated by Bender and Cotton Petroleum and supported by Finkelstein and subsequent cases, we do not deem the recent criticism of the Gillespie doctrine pertinent here.”); Travelstead v. Derwinski, 978 F.2d 1244, 1249 (Fed. Cir. 1992) (remand of decision denying waiver of indebtedness on veteran’s home loan; the “principal directive of Finkelstein is that remands are not all of the same nature. Some are final, some are not.”); St. Francis Med. Ctr. v. Sullivan, 962 F.2d 1110, 1114 (3d Cir. 1992) (remand overturning agency’s refusal of Medicare provider’s request for hearing on reimbursement claim).

Rivkind, 825 F.2d 1501, 1504 (11th Cir. 1987) (remand to reconsider asylum application); AJA Assocs. v. Army Corps of Eng’rs, 817 F.2d 1070, 1073 (3d Cir. 1987) (remand for informal oral hearing on dredge-and-fill permit); Huie v. Bowen, 788 F.2d 698, 701-03 (11th Cir. 1986) (voluntary remand to apply new law and impose retrospective benefits to claimant); Regents of the Univ. of Calif. v. Heckler, 771 F.2d 1182, 1186-87 (9th Cir. 1985) (remand to revise regulation to comply with governing statute), overruled on other grounds, Good Samaritan Hosp. v. footnotes.footnote_text: Writing in 1989, the D.C. Circuit explained that the courts of appeals had “uniformly held that, as a general rule,” remands to administrative agencies are not final and appealable, with an “exception” for agency appellants. Although that rule produce “asymmetrical results”—private parties cannot appeal while agencies can—“that asymmetry derives . . . from the formulation of the Cohen test, under which the question of appealability turns to a great extent on whether a putative appellant could challenge the remand order after a final determination on the merits.” Occidental Petroleum Corp., 873 F.2d at 331-32.

citations.citation_text: Writing in 1989, the D.C. Circuit explained that the courts of appeals had “uniformly held that, as a general rule,” remands to administrative agencies are not final and appealable, with an “exception” for agency appellants. footnotes.footnote_text: There were exceptions, the most notable being the Tenth Circuit’s decision in Bender. There the court concluded that the collateral-order doctrine did not apply to an agency’s appeal of a remand, but that the court nonetheless had jurisdiction under a “practical application” of 28 U.S.C. § 1291 “viewed under the circumstances of each case.” 744 F.2d at 1427. But this is a distinction without a difference. The collateral-order doctrine itself arises from a notion of “practical” finality, Cohen, 337 U.S. at 546, meaning that the circuit courts’ prudential development of circumstances in which remands are final always boils down to a “practical construction of finality.” Kreider Dairy Farms, Inc., 190 F.3d at 124 (Sloviter, J., concurring); see also Lammon, supra note 13, 51 U. Rich. L. Rev. at 377 (explaining that the lines between these doctrines are murky, the collateral-order doctrine is probably best understood as an application of the “practical finality” doctrine, and the collateral-order doctrine is now the most common example of prudential balancing “the interests between immediate review and delaying appeals”).

But this is a distinction without a difference. The collateral-order doctrine itself arises from a notion of “practical” finality, Cohen, 337 U.S. at 546, meaning that the circuit courts’ prudential development of circumstances in which remands are final always boils down to a “practical construction of finality.” Kreider Dairy Farms, Inc., 190 F.3d at 124 (Sloviter, J., concurring); see also Lammon, supra note 13, 51 U. Rich. L. Rev. at 377 (explaining that the lines between these doctrines are murky, the collateral-order doctrine is probably best understood as an application of the “practical finality” doctrine, and the collateral-order doctrine is now the most common example of prudential balancing “the interests between immediate review and delaying appeals”).

footnotes.footnote_text: A consistent exception are remands of remedy orders under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (“IDEA”), 20 U.S.C. § 1400 et seq. Such remands are not appealable, even by school districts and educational boards. See, e.g., S.S. by and through A.S. v. Cobb Cnty. Sch. Dist., 43 F.4th 1165, 1171 (11th Cir. 2022) (collecting cases); C.W. by and through B.W., 994 F.3d at 1222; Shapiro v. Paradise Valley Unified Sch. Dist., 152 F.3d 1159, 1160-61 (9th Cir. 1998) (per curiam). Another, less consistent exception are remands to Employee Retirement Income Security Act (“ERISA”) administrators. Some circuits allow appeals by administrators while others do not. See, e.g., Mead v. Reliastar Life Ins. Co., 768 F.3d 102, 108 (2d Cir. 2014) (discussing circuits’ differing approaches). Finally, there are rare, ad hoc exceptions. See, e.g., World Fuel Corp. v. Geithner, 568 F.3d 1345, 1349 (11th Cir. 2009) (Office of Foreign Assets Control in U.S. Treasury Department could not appeal remand directing it to develop new legal standard under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act); see also Miami Tribe of Okla. v. United States, 656 F.3d 1129, 1140 (10th Cir. 2011) (explaining that prior remand would not have been appealable by agency because it contemplated further district-court proceedings); Nat’l Air Traffic Controllers Ass’n v. Sec’y of Transp., No. 06-3466, 2007 WL 2141941, *3 (6th Cir. 2007) (per curiam) (in rejecting appeal of remand by plaintiffs, stating that even the agency would not be able to appeal given the limited nature of the remand).

footnotes.footnote_text: Professor Lammon does a heroic job of explaining the relationship between finality, practical finality, Gillespie case-by-case balancing, and the collateral-order doctrine. See Lammon, supra note 13, 51 U. Rich. L. Rev. at 373-74. He also rightly points out that the administrative-remand rule is best conceived of as a “true finality rule”—i.e., appeals from remands come at the effective end of litigation, if not the end of agency proceedings. Lammon, supra note 13, 93 Wash. L. Rev. at 1834-35. But, as he acknowledges, there is “confusion that sometimes arises in determining when the end of district court proceedings is a final decision.” Id. at 1836. The result is that many circuits continue to examine appeals from remands under the collateral-order doctrine, which provides for interlocutory review of decidedly non-final orders. See 15B Fed. Prac. & Proc. Juris. § 3914.32.

citations.citation_text: Professor Lammon does a heroic job of explaining the relationship between finality, practical finality, Gillespie case-by-case balancing, and the collateral-order doctrine. See Lammon, supra note 13, 51 U. Rich. L. Rev. at 373-74. He also rightly points out that the administrative-remand rule is best conceived of as a “true finality rule”—i.e., appeals from remands come at the effective end of litigation, if not the end of agency proceedings. Lammon, supra note 13, 93 Wash. L. Rev. at 1834-35. But, as he acknowledges, there is “confusion that sometimes arises in determining when the end of district court proceedings is a final decision.” Id. at 1836. The result is that many circuits continue to examine appeals from remands under the collateral-order doctrine, which provides for interlocutory review of decidedly non-final orders. See 15B Fed. Prac. & Proc. Juris. § 3914.32.

footnotes.footnote_text: Papotto, 731 F.3d at 270 (citing Kreider, 190 F.3d at 118). Papotto was an ERISA case but announced the Third Circuit’s rule for all administrative-agency remands. It and Kreider synthesized this test from prior cases applying various combinations of the collateral-order doctrine’s three criteria. See, e.g., Bhd. of Maint. of Way Emps. v. Consol. Rail Corp., 864 F.2d 283, 286 (3d Cir. 1988) (“Our precedent holds that when the issue on appeal is limited to the right to a procedure that once granted is not susceptible as a practical matter to subsequent review, remand orders directing such procedures are final.”); AJA Assocs., 817 F.2d at 1073 (agency could appeal remand that could not receive later appellate review); United Steelworkers of Am. Local 1913 v. Union R.R. Co., 648 F.2d 905, 910 (3d Cir. 1981) (railroad company could appeal remand to railway labor board that effectively ended the litigation and involved issue that would be unreviewable later).

footnotes.footnote_text: In Shipbuilders Council of America, the Fourth Circuit found jurisdiction over part of the private intervenor-defendant’s appeal because the agency also appealed. As to other parts of the intervenor-defendant’s appeal, the court stated that it “need not reach the question of whether such an order could be appealed by a party other than the agency, because the order itself is not final and therefore not properly subject to review under the collateral order doctrine.” 578 F.3d at 240. And in Culbertson v. Sec’y of Health & Hum. Servs., 859 F.2d 319, 323 (4th Cir. 1988), the Fourth Circuit found jurisdiction over an individual claimant’s appeal of a remand to the Social Security Agency. The court nodded to practical finality and the now-defunct “death knell” doctrine but relied most on the idea that the remand would lead to a final denial of the claim (i.e., it effectively ended the litigation).

citations.citation_text: In Shipbuilders Council of America, the Fourth Circuit found jurisdiction over part of the private intervenor-defendant’s appeal because the agency also appealed. And in Culbertson v. Sec’y of Health & Hum. Servs., 859 F.2d 319, 323 (4th Cir. 1988), the Fourth Circuit found jurisdiction over an individual claimant’s appeal of a remand to the Social Security Agency. The court nodded to practical finality and the now-defunct “death knell” doctrine but relied most on the idea that the remand would lead to a final denial of the claim (i.e., it effectively ended the litigation).

Many unpublished decisions reach the same result. See, e.g., Montana Env’t Info. Ctr., 2023 WL 8166779, at *1 (intervenor-defendant mining company could not appeal remand to agency; separability and wasted proceeding criteria were met, but unreviewability criterion was not).

footnotes.footnote_text: That is, an appeal may lie from a remand in a case involving a challenge to an agency’s rule (legislative), or where the agency is acting as a party to an action (adversarial), rather than as a decision-making body (adjudicative). The “adversarial” category is the most confusing; the Tenth Circuit’s most illuminating discussion of it is in American Wild Horse Preservation Campaign v. Jewell, 847 F.3d 1174, 1185 (10th Cir. 2016). “Adjudicative” agency actions may still be subject to appeal, though far less frequently than “legislative” or “adversarial” ones.

The “adversarial” category is the most confusing; the Tenth Circuit’s most illuminating discussion of it is in American Wild Horse Preservation Campaign v. footnotes.footnote_text: See Merit Energy Co., LLC v. Haaland, Nos. 21-8047 and 21-8048, 2022 WL 17844513, *4 (10th Cir. 2022) (administrative-remand rule did not bar plaintiffs’ appeal of remand because relevant agency decision was “quasi-legislative” or adversarial, and the remand effectively ended the litigation); Am. Wild Horse Pres. Campaign, 847 F.3d at 1184-85 (plaintiff could appeal remand because agency decision was adversarial). Compare, e.g., Cotton Petroleum Corp., 870 F.2d at 1522 (applying Bender test to allow appeal of remand by plaintiffs) with, e.g., W. Energy Alliance v. Salazar, 709 F.3d 1040, 1049-51 (10th Cir. 2013) (remand of land-use plan not final as to plaintiffs because “importance” and “urgency” criteria unmet); S. Utah Wilderness Alliance v. Kempthorne, 525 F.3d 966, 970 (10th Cir. 2008) (remand of decision approving oil and gas leases on public lands not final as to proposed intervenor-defendant lessees because “importance” and “urgency” criteria were unmet); Rocky Mtn. Wild v. Dallas, Nos. 17-1366 and 17-1413, 2018 WL 11225766, *4-5 (10th Cir. 2018) (remand to U.S. Forest Service not final as to intervenor-defendants); Dine Citizens Against Ruining Our Env’t v. Klein, 439 Fed. Appx. 679, 681-82 (10th Cir. 2011) (remand of decision granting application to revise mining plan not final as to intervenor-defendant mining company; issue “important” but not “urgent” and could be reviewed later).

footnotes.footnote_text: See, e.g., Cherokee Nation v. Bernhardt, 936 F.3d 1142, 1152 (10th Cir. 2019) (allowing appeal by intervenor-defendant tribe where agency also appealed). Even when they do so, the courts often still evaluate whether the remand is appealable by intervenors. See, e.g., Crow Indian Tribe, 965 F.3d at 676 (court had jurisdiction to consider intervenor-defendants’ appeal of remand on issue not covered by agency appeal because issue was “conclusively determined by the district court and cannot be taken into account in the [agency] proceedings on remand”). And the courts are careful to limit their review to the issues the agency raises. See, e.g., Zen Magnets, LLC, 968 F.3d at 1165-66 (holding Ninth Circuit lacked jurisdiction over those portions of plaintiff’s cross-appeal of remand that were not covered by government’s appeal because later-unreviewability factor was absent).

citations.citation_text: See, e.g., Cherokee Nation v. Bernhardt, 936 F.3d 1142, 1152 (10th Cir. 2019) (allowing appeal by intervenor-defendant tribe where agency also appealed). See, e.g., Crow Indian Tribe, 965 F.3d at 676 (court had jurisdiction to consider intervenor-defendants’ appeal of remand on issue not covered by agency appeal because issue was “conclusively determined by the district court and cannot be taken into account in the [agency] proceedings on remand”). And the courts are careful to limit their review to the issues the agency raises. See, e.g., Zen Magnets, LLC, 968 F.3d at 1165-66 (holding Ninth Circuit lacked jurisdiction over those portions of plaintiff’s cross-appeal of remand that were not covered by government’s appeal because later-unreviewability factor was absent).

footnotes.footnote_text: Probably before now I should have offered this possible defense of the Ninth Circuit’s variance (trenchantly raised by the intrepid editors of the Stanford Law Review): Apart from the D.C. Circuit, the Ninth Circuit sees more APA cases than any other circuit. See Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts, Table C-3—U.S. District Courts—Civil Cases Filed, by Jurisdiction, Nature of Suit, and District (12 months ending June 30, 2025) (downloadable .xlsx), https://www.uscourts.gov/data-news/reports/statistical-reports/statistical-tables-federal-judiciary/statistical-tables-federal-judiciary-june-2025?utm_source=chatgpt.com (author calculations aggregating APA cases across districts within each circuit). More occasions to apply (or not) the administrative-remand rule could mean greater variance in outcomes. A future empirical analysis could compare the number of non-agency appeals of APA remands, and the number of such appeals permitted, across the circuits.

footnotes.footnote_text: See Bruce Johnsen & Moin A. Yahya, “The Evolution of Sherman Act Jurisdiction: A Roadmap for Competitive Federalism,” 7 U. Pa. J. Const. L. 403, 460 (2004) (“Regulatory statutes inject sudden uncertainty into a common law judicial system based on stare decisis, which is ideally suited to incremental adjustments in response to changing circumstances. Absent established precedent or clear understanding of the statute's objective, a common law system begins a slow iterative process of case-by-case adjudication to resolve the uncertainty.”).

Roper, 445 U.S. 326, 333-34 (1980) (“Ordinarily, only a party aggrieved by a judgment or order of a district court may exercise the statutory right to appeal therefrom. A party who receives all that he has sought generally is not aggrieved by the judgment affording the relief and cannot appeal from it. The rule is one of federal appellate practice, however, derived from the statutes granting appellate jurisdiction and the historic practices of the appellate courts; it does not have its source in the jurisdictional limitations of Art[icle] III.” (Internal citations omitted.)).

footnotes.footnote_text: As the Ninth Circuit put it in U.S. Board of Water Commissioners, “remand orders are sufficiently ‘final’ under § 1291, where the relief sought by appellants cannot possibly be achieved through the district court’s directions.” 893 F.3d at 595. Compare Cottonwood Env’t Law Ctr., 2022 WL 612673, at *1 (rejecting appeal by plaintiff of remand requiring further environmental review) with Neighbors Against Bison Slaughter, 2022 WL 1315302, at *1 (allowing appeal by another plaintiff in same case of portion of remand denying request to impose a strict deadline for further environmental review to be completed). The Eighth Circuit implicitly recognized denial of relief as a basis for appealing a remand as far back as 1967, see Bohms, 381 F.2d at 285, and the Supreme Court picked up on it in Finkelstein, 496 U.S. at 623 n.3. And of course the concern about meaningless remands seeps into multiple areas. See Walker, supra note 31, 101 Iowa L. Rev. Online at 87-88 (discussing cases in which courts, especially the Ninth Circuit, refuse to follow the ordinary-remand rule).

citations.citation_text: As the Ninth Circuit put it in U.S. Board of Water Commissioners, “remand orders are sufficiently ‘final’ under § 1291, where the relief sought by appellants cannot possibly be achieved through the district court’s directions.” 893 F.3d at 595. Compare Cottonwood Env’t Law Ctr., 2022 WL 612673, at *1 (rejecting appeal by plaintiff of remand requiring further environmental review) with Neighbors Against Bison Slaughter, 2022 WL 1315302, at *1 (allowing appeal by another plaintiff in same case of portion of remand denying request to impose a strict deadline for further environmental review to be completed). The Eighth Circuit implicitly recognized denial of relief as a basis for appealing a remand as far back as 1967, see Bohms, 381 F.2d at 285, and the Supreme Court picked up on it in Finkelstein, 496 U.S. at 623 n.3. And of course the concern about meaningless remands seeps into multiple areas. See Walker, supra note 31, 101 Iowa L. Rev. Online at 87-88 (discussing cases in which courts, especially the Ninth Circuit, refuse to follow the ordinary-remand rule).

footnotes.footnote_text: Id. at 598, 601 (Friedland and Bennett, JJ., concurring). Alternatively they suggest that remands with vacatur are the functional equivalent of an injunction, appealable under 28 U.S.C. § 1292(a), or that they should be appealable “under the traditional collateral order doctrine, without the modifications to that test reflected in” the Ninth Circuit’s administrative-remand rule. Id. at 698 n.5; see also Mont. Wildlife Fed’n v. Haaland, 127 F.4th 1, 27-30 (9th Cir. 2025) (discussing appealability of remands that are and are not injunctive in nature). As to the latter, that approach would not work in circuits in which the administrative-remand rule and collateral-order doctrine are co-extensive (e.g., the Third and Fourth Circuits).

footnotes.footnote_text: I will admit there are differences between the two cases. Unlike in Friends of Hope Valley, in Sierra Forest Legacy the challenged decision was not vacated (but the Forest Service agreed to stay the decision pending appeal), and the Forest Service had already completed much of the remand process by the time the Ninth Circuit issued its decision. 646 F.3d at 1175-76. These facts increased the likelihood of a “meaningless remand” in Sierra Forest Legacy. Still, that possibility was high in Friends of Hope Valley when the Ninth Circuit heard argument and issued its decision.

citations.citation_text: I will admit there are differences between the two cases. Still, that possibility was high in Friends of Hope Valley when the Ninth Circuit heard argument and issued its decision.

footnotes.footnote_text: See, e.g., Gallatin Wildlife Ass’n, 743 Fed. Appx. at 755 (Ninth Circuit); Miami Tribe of Okla., 656 F.3d at 1139 n.12 (Tenth Circuit); Utah State Dep’t of Health v. Kennecott Corp., 14 F.3d 1489, 1495 (10th Cir. 1994); Cabot Corp., 788 F.2d at 1543 (Federal Circuit); see also McCoy, 683 F.2d at 1141 n.2 (Eighth Circuit holding en banc that, absent section 1292(b) certification, the remand would not have been final and appealable), abrogated by Finkelstein, 496 U.S. 617; 15A Wright & Miller, Federal Practice & Procedure § 3913 (3d ed.) (“Interlocutory review can be achieved as to matters outside [specifically delineated categories] by joint permission of the district court and court of appeals under § 1292(b). . . .”).  Rule 54(b) permits a district court to “direct entry of a final judgment as to one or more, but fewer than all, claims or parties,” but “only if the court expressly determines that there is no just reason for delay.” Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b). Meanwhile, 28 U.S.C. 1292(b) vests a circuit with jurisdiction over an otherwise unappealable order where (1) a district court determines that the “order involves a controlling question of law as to which there is substantial ground for difference of opinion and that an immediate appeal from the order may materially advance the ultimate termination of the litigation,” and (2) the circuit court chooses to hear the appeal. 28 U.S.C. § 1292(b).

footnotes.footnote_text: The Tenth Circuit reached the same conclusion in allowing an agency to appeal a remand following a favorable final judgment. The administrative-remand rule, the court explained, “avoids the perverse incentive [of] encouraging an agency to seek an immediate appeal of a remand order (even if it was unlikely the case fell within the practical finality exception) if the agency had a whiff that we would take jurisdiction over the interlocutory appeal.” Miami Tribe of Okla., 656 F.3d at 1141. Fearing exactly this line of thinking, some agencies indicate when accepting a court-ordered remand that they do so “under protest.” See Viraj Grp., Ltd. v. v. United States, 343 F.3d 1371, 1376 (Fed. Cir. 2003); Lynch, supra note 13, at 388-89 (discussing this practice).

footnotes.footnote_text: See supra note 175 and accompanying text. I also agree with the Tenth Circuit that the type of agency decision at issue in a case (adversarial, legislative, or adjudicative) may help determine whether the administrative-remand rule should apply. See supra note 174 and accompanying text. But those distinctions can be confusing, and I wonder whether they may unwittingly cement undesirable asymmetries in the appealability of remands by different parties.

footnotes.footnote_text: As the Tenth Circuit implicitly recognized long ago, few remands are truly separable from the merits, as the collateral-order doctrine traditionally requires. Bender, 744 F.2d at 1427. More commonly, remands resolve one merits issue that is separable from others. See, e.g., Littlefield, 951 F.3d at 36 (remand flowing from summary judgment for plaintiffs on their first cause of action was “separable,” allowing tribal defendants to appeal). Thus, for APA remands, “separability” is appropriately construed loosely.

citations.citation_text: As the Tenth Circuit implicitly recognized long ago, few remands are truly separable from the merits, as the collateral-order doctrine traditionally requires. Bender, 744 F.2d at 1427. More commonly, remands resolve one merits issue that is separable from others. See, e.g., Littlefield, 951 F.3d at 36 (remand flowing from summary judgment for plaintiffs on their first cause of action was “separable,” allowing tribal defendants to appeal). Thus, for APA remands, “separability” is appropriately construed loosely.

footnotes.footnote_text: Famous last words? Federal Practice and Procedure and others would no doubt think so. See, e.g., 15B Fed. Prac. & Proc. Juris. § 3914.32 (“It would be nearly as difficult to administer a collateral order appeal doctrine relying on a case-by-case assessment of the probable burdens imposed by further administrative proceedings.”); 15A Fed. Prac. & Proc. Juris. § 3913 (“Undoubtedly there are cases in which allowing appeal from orders not now deemed appealable would improve the administration of justice. The total number of such cases is no doubt substantial. An open-ended balancing approach to finality, however, would undermine the residual clarity that has been the most important virtue of finality doctrine.”).
